ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Central Auditory Processing Disorder (secondary to right insular/internal capsule hemorrhage)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Normal peripheral hearing sensitivity with specific deficits on the Dichotic Rhyme Test (left ear) and an electrode effect on MLR (right hemisphere), consistent with the confirmed right insular/internal capsule lesion.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To identify the cause of sudden collapse, hemiplegia, and sensory deficits.
To assess peripheral hearing sensitivity given complaints of hearing loss and difficulty in noise.
To evaluate speech recognition abilities in quiet.
To assess central auditory function given normal peripheral hearing and complaints of amusia and difficulty in noise.
To objectively evaluate the integrity of the central auditory pathways and check for laterality effects.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Peripheral hearing sensitivity and speech recognition in quiet were normal, ruling out peripheral pathology. Central testing revealed a specific deficit in the left ear on the Dichotic Rhyme Test (contralateral to the right-sided lesion) and a significant electrode effect over the right hemisphere (T4) on MLR. These findings confirm central auditory dysfunction associated with the right insular and internal capsule lesion.

tests.name: Radiology (CT Scan)
tests.result_summary: Vascular lesion involving the right insula, lenticular process, and internal and external capsules.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Speech recognition scores were normal bilaterally.

tests.name: Central Auditory Processing Evaluation (Behavioral)
tests.result_summary: Normal performance on dichotic digits, frequency patterns, and duration patterns. Marked deficit for the left ear and above-normal performance for the right ear on the Dichotic Rhyme Test (consistent on retest).

tests.name: Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.result_summary: Considerable asymmetry with reduced responses for the T4 electrode site (right hemisphere) for both right and left ear stimulations, indicating an electrode effect.

proposed_items: Metacognitive strategies for dealing with background noise
counseling_actions: Explain that the hearing difficulty is central (brain-based) and related to the right insular lesion, not peripheral.
Validate complaints of hearing loss, difficulty in noise, and amusia as physiological consequences of the stroke.
Discuss the MLR electrode effect as confirmation of the deep brain lesion affecting auditory pathways.

escalation.rationale_short: Patient is already under care for stroke rehabilitation; audiological management is for sequelae.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor functional status and efficacy of coping strategies.

expected_outcome: Patient continues to have problems hearing in noise.
Various coping strategies have helped, but only marginally.
Patient carries out most everyday activities successfully.
Subsequent audiological testing showed results similar to the initial evaluation.
